thread.title: New Orleans' food scene did more than just bounce back post Katrina [Photos]
thread.title_full: New Orleans' food scene did more than just bounce back post Katrina [Photos]

title: New Orleans' food scene did more than just bounce back post Katrina [Photos]
text:
Rebecca Santana, THE ASSOCIATED PRESS First posted: Friday, August 28, 2015 11:41 AM EDT New Orleans' food scene Previous Next 
Bartender Diana Fisher serves up cocktails at the High Hat Cafe on Freret Street in New Orleans, Saturday, Aug. 22, 2015. The U.S. Census Bureau reports there are 11 percent more restaurants in the metro area than in 2005, even though the population is smaller than pre-Katrina. The growth is coming in more casual, mid-range restaurants, and it�s fueled largely by a rebound in tourism as well as an influx of millennials seeking an affordable city with culture. (AP Photo/Gerald Herbert) AP 
Food is prepared in the kitchen at �Namese� in New Orleans, a Vietnamese restaurant, which infuses the famous flavors of New Orleans with traditional Asian favorites, Monday, Aug. 17, 2015. New Orleans is a city where eating has long been a serious business. But 10 years ago, that seemed imperiled when Hurricane Katrina and the levee breaches that flooded the coast threatened that rich culinary history. (AP Photo/Max Becherer) AP 
A classic serving of shrimp creole is served at Cafe Dauphine in New Orleans, Wednesday, Aug. 26, 2015. For now, the post-Katrina restaurant boom has only one outpost in the Lower 9th Ward, one of the city�s hardest-hit neighborhoods. Longtime resident Keisha Henry opened Cafe Dauphine with relatives, marking a rare sit-down restaurant in an area that traditionally has had only corner stores and takeout.(AP Photo/Gerald Herbert) AP 
An order of classic spring rolls is plated and ready to be served at the "Namese" restaurant in New Orleans, Monday, Aug. 17, 2015. �Namese,� a Vietnamese restaurant in New Orleans, which infuses the famous flavors of New Orleans with traditional Asian favorites. New Orleans is a city where eating has long been a serious business. But 10 years ago, that seemed imperiled when Hurricane Katrina and the levee breaches that flooded the coast threatened that rich culinary history. (AP Photo/Max Becherer) AP 
Keisha Henry poses for a photo outside her Cafe Dauphine, in the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans, Tuesday, Aug. 25, 2015. For now, the post-Katrina restaurant boom has only one outpost in the Lower 9th Ward, one of the city�s hardest-hit neighborhoods. Longtime resident Keisha Henry opened Cafe Dauphine with relatives, marking a rare sit-down restaurant in an area that traditionally has had only corner stores and takeout. (AP Photo/Gerald Herbert) AP
